referred_to_by.content: American, Sun Prairie, Wisconsin 1887–1986 Santa Fe, New Mexico
Alfred Stieglitz Collection, Bequest of Georgia O'Keeffe, 1986

Throughout the 1920s O'Keeffe spent several months of each year (from spring to fall) at the Stieglitz family estate in Lake George, New York.  Trees—maples, pines, poplars, and birches—were abundant there. O'Keeffe portrayed them singly or in groves, and often reflected the changes of the seasons in their colors.  When she later moved to New Mexico, trees—particularly yellow cottonwoods—were again a source of inspiration.
Inscription: Initialed (verso, in center of five-pointed star, in graphite): OK
the artist (1925–d. 1986; her bequest as part of the Alfred Stieglitz Collection to MMA)
